english_translation: of or belonging to the people
definition: of or belonging to the people, common, non-elite
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'laos' meaning 'people'
example: Η λαϊκή ζωή είναι σταθερά στην ιστορία.
Laïkí zoí eínai stathérá stin historía.
The popular life is constant in history.

definition: the scientific study of plants and their structures, life cycle, and interactions with the environment
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'phuton' meaning 'plant'
example: Η φυτεία είναι μια σπουδαιολογική επιστήμη.
I futeía eínai mia spoudaiologikí epistími.
Botany is a scientific discipline.

definition: a material object worshiped for its supposed spiritual or sacred powers, or as a representation of a deity
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'eidos' meaning 'shape, form'
example: Το είδωλο της θεάς ήταν στον ιερό.
To eídolo tis theás ítan ston ieró.
The goddess' idol was in the temple.

definition: food provided to animals, typically as a dietary supplement or to improve their health
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek words 'zoon' meaning 'animal' and 'trophe' meaning 'nourishment, food'
example: Η ζωοτροφή είναι σημαντική για την υγεία των ζώων.
I zootrofí eínai simantikí gia tin ygeía ton zóon.
Animal feed is important for the health of the animals.

definition: causing fear, awe, or dread
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'phriké' meaning 'fear, panic'
example: Τα φρικαλεότερα ζώα είναι τα τέρατα της ζούγκλας.
Ta frikaleótera zóa eínai ta tératá tis zoúnglas.
The most frightening animals are the monsters of the jungle.

definition: food, sustenance, or support required for survival and growth
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'trophe' meaning 'nourishment, food'
example: Η τροφή στην ζούγκλα είναι πολύ δύσκολη.
I trofí stin zoúngla eínai polý dýskoli.
Nourishment in the jungle is very difficult.

definition: related to exploration, seeking out new and unknown territories
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'ektopízein' meaning 'to explore'
example: Οι εκτοπιστικοί ταξιδευτές εξερευνούν τη ζούγκλα στην αναζήτηση νέων σπουδαίων ανακαλύψεων.
I ektopistikí taxideftés exerevnoun ti zoúngla stin anazítisí neón spoudaíon anakalýpseon.
Exploratory travelers explore the jungle in search of new and exciting discoveries.
Το κλίμα της ζ

definition: a state of utter confusion or disorder
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word χάος (chaos), which meant 'vast chasm or emptiness'
example: Το χάος στη ζούγκλα ήταν ανεπαίσθητο.
The chaos in the jungle was palpable.
Το χάος στη ζούγκλα ήταν αισθητό.

definition: a dense forest in a tropical region, typically uninhabited by humans
etymology: Derived from the Sanskrit word जंगल (jangala), which meant 'arid, uncultivated land'
example: Η ζούγκλα ήταν μια παραδειγματική εκτοπιστική περιοχή.
The jungle was a prototypical wilderness area.
Η ζούγκλα ήταν μια παράδειγματική περιοχή εκτοπισμού.

definition: a person who hunts game or other wild animals for food or sport
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek verb θηρέω (thireo), which meant 'to hunt, to chase'
example: Ο θηρευτής περάσαμε δύο ημέρες στη ζούγκλα.
The hunter spent two days in the jungle.
Ο θηρευτής περήφανε δ

definition: a person who attacks and robs ships at sea
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek verb πειράζω (peirazo), which meant 'to attack, to attempt'
example: Ο πειρατής είχε στολήσει την πλοία του στη ζούγκλα.
The pirate had moored his ship in the jungle.
Ο πειρατής είχε στεγνώσει το πλοίο του στη ζούγκλα.

definition: a person who travels to or examines new or little-k
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek verb πληροφορέω (pler
example: Ο πλανήτης έκανε μια εκσκαφή στη ζούγκλα.
The explorer conducted an excavation in the jungle.
Ο πλανήτης έγινε μια ανασκαφή στη ζούγκλα.

definition: serving as a characteristic example of a type
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word παράδειγμα (para
example: Η ζούγκλα ήταν παραδειγματική για τη ζωή στον παραδ

definition: a dense growth of trees, shrubs, and undergrowth covering a large area
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'dassein' meaning to divide or divide off.
example: Το δάσος ήταν μαγευτικό στον περιηγητή.
To dasos itan mageftiko ston periegititi.
The forest was enchanting to the traveler.

definition: a vehicle for conveying goods or passengers on water
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'barus' meaning heavy.
example: Οι πειρατές χρησιμοποιούσαν βάρκες για να πλέουν στον Παγκόσμιο Ωκεανό.
I pirates chrisimopoiousan varkes gia na pleoun ston Pagkósmio Okeano.
Pirates used boats to sail on the World Ocean.

definition: a narrow passage of water connecting two larger bodies of water
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'steno' meaning narrow.
example: Το στενάγμα ήταν σημαντικό για την επικοινωνία μεταξύ των πολιτιστικών κοινοτήτων.
To stenagma itan simantiko gia tin epikoinonia metaksi ton politistikon koinotiton.
The strait was important for communication between cultural communities.

definition: an overhead covering, typically made of fabric, supported by poles and used as a shelter
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'teinein' meaning to stretch.
example: Το τέντο είναι σημαντικό για να προστατεύει από τον ήλιο τους περιηγητές του δάσους.
To tento einai simantiko gia na prostateyi apo ton ilio tous periegites tou dasous.
The canopy is important to protect the jungle travelers from the sun.

definition: the land near the sea, especially along the edge of a continent or an island
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'cheir' meaning hand.
example: Το χέρσο ήταν ενα περισσότερο ήσυχο μέρος του δάσους.
To cherso itan ena perissotero ischio meros tou dasous.
The coast was a quieter part of the jungle.

definition: a shelter made of fabric supported by poles, typically used for camping
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'skene' meaning stage or tent.
example: Οι πειρατές φτιάχνουν σκηνές για να παραμείνουν εναντίον της βροχής.
I pirates ftiachnoun skenes gia na paramenoun enantion tis vrochis.
Pirates make tents to stay protected from the rain.

definition: A dense collection of trees and underbrush covering a large area of land
etymology: The word comes from ancient Greek, possibly from the verb 'δαίδαλλαι' (daídallein), meaning 'to tear apart, to rend'
example: Το δάσος ήταν μαγευτικό και τα πειραστικά σκάνδαλα είχαν παρασαγγειλεί.
To dasos ítan mageftiko kai ta pirate skándala eíchan parasangeilí.
The forest was magical and the pirate's    traps had been revealed.

definition: A large, carnivorous feline found primarily in the jungles of Central and South America
etymology: The word comes from ancient Greek 'Γαλάτης' (Galátis), meaning Gaul, and 'παρανίνης' (paranínēs), meaning panther, as the jaguar was thought to resemble a panther found in Gaul.
example: Ο γαλατόπαροινος είναι ένας από τους πιο δεινούς πειραστές του δάσους.
O galatoparinos eínai énas apó tous pio deinous pirate tou dasous.
The jaguar is one of the fiercest predators of the forest.

definition: A person who travels to unknown or little-known regions in order to gain knowledge of them
etymology: The word comes from ancient Greek 'εντοπίζειν' (entopízein), meaning 'to find out'

definition: a creature or being that is often of immense size or power and is typically considered to be dangerous or evil.
etymology: The word 'teras' comes from the ancient Greek word for wonder or marvel.
example: Τερας από την ζούγκλα τερεί.
Teras apo tin zounkla teri.
A monster from the jungle terrorizes.

definition: intended to discover new information or gain a greater understanding of a particular subject or place.
etymology: The word 'entopistikos' comes from the ancient Greek word 'entopisis' meaning 'investigation' or 'exploration'
example: Οι εντοπιστικοί περιηγητές ανακαλύπτουν την ζούγκλα.
Oi entopistikoi periitites anakalupoun tin zounkla.
The exploratory explorers discover the jungle.

definition: an area of darkness, caused by light being blocked by a solid object, that is cast onto a surface.
etymology: The word 'skiá' comes from the ancient Greek word for 'shade' or 'darkness'
example: Η σκιά των δέντρων στην ζούγκλα είναι μαγική.
I skiá ton dentron stin zounkla einai magikí.
The shadow of the trees in the jungle is magical.

definition: having great size or magnitude, big in physical size, large in quantity or number
etymology: Unknown
example: Το μέγας δέντρο στο βουνό.
To megas dentro sto vouno.
The big tree in the mountain.

definition: a test of someone's abilities or integrity, a dangerous or difficult situation that tests a person's courage and endura nce, an enticement to do something wrong or unwise
etymology: Derived from 'peira' meaning 'to try, to test'
example: Τους πειρασμούς και τις σκάψεις που ήταν υπόκεινται στη ζούγκλα.
Tous peirasmous ke tis skapseis pou itan ypokentaite sti zougla.
The trials and hardships they were subjected to in the jungle.

definition: lacking moisture, lacking interest or emotion
etymology: Unknown
example: Ο ξηρός χώρος στο βόρειο τμήμα της ζούγκλας.
O xeros horos sto voreio tmima tis zouglas.
The dry area in the northern part of the jungle.

definition: Of or relating to a tropical climate, vegetation or region.
etymology: Derived from the ancient greek word 'φαραγγίς' (pharangis) meaning 'jungle'
example: Οι φαραγγίτικοι παραλίες έχουν έναν πανέμορφο θάματο.
Oi pharangitikoi paralies ehoune enan panemorfo thamato.
The tropical beaches have a beautiful sand.

definition: A dense collection of trees, shrubs, and undergrowth, typically covering a large area of land.
etymology: Derived from the ancient greek word 'δάσος' (dasos) meaning 'a dense forest'
example: Η δασέα ήταν πλούσια σε ζώα και φυτά.
I dasea itan plousia se zoa ke fyta.
The forest was rich in animals and plants.

definition: A person who attacks and robs ships at sea.
etymology: Derived from the ancient greek word 'πειράομαι' (peiraomai) meaning 'to attempt, to try'
example: Οι πείρατες επιτίθενται στα πλοία και κλέβουν τα αγαθά τους.
Oi peirates epitithentai sta ploia ke

definition: relating to the entire world; affecting or encompassing the entire earth
etymology: Derived from the Greek words 'πᾶν' (pan), meaning 'all' and 'κόσμος' (kosmos), meaning 'world' or 'universe'.
example: ἐκ τῶν παγκοσμίων φυτειῶν, πολλά εἰσιν τῶν θεραπευτικῶν.
ek tōn pagkosmíōn phyteiōn, pollá eisin tōn therapeutikōn.
From the global plants, many are therapeutic.

definition: food or sustenance specifically for animals
etymology: Derived from the Greek words 'ζῷον' (zōion), meaning 'animal' and 'τροφή' (trophē), meaning 'nourishment' or 'food'.
example: Τίνα ζωοτροφήν φαγόντες οἱ θηρεύοντες;
Tína zōotrofēn phagóntes hoi theureúontes;
What kind of animal food do the hunters eat?

definition: a dense forest in a tropical region, typically uninhabited by humans
etymology: The origin of this word is uncertain, but it is thought to possibly come from a West African language.
example: Τί ζούγκλας εἰσιν ταῖς λαϊκαῖς περιοχαῖς;
Tí zouglás eisin tais laïkais periokhais;
What jungles are in the rural areas?

definition: A large area covered with trees and undergrowth, typically in a tropical region
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word δάσος meaning 'thicket' or 'forest'
example: Το δάσος ήταν πλούσιο σε βιότοπο και ζωή.
To dasos itan plousio se viotopo ke zoí.
The forest was rich in habitat and life.

definition: A portable shelter made of cloth, supported by one or more poles and stretched tight by cords or loops attached to pegs driven into the ground
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word σκηνή meaning 'tent' or 'hut'
example: Οι πειρατές φτιάχνουν σκηνικές για να προστατεύσουν από τον βροχό.
I piratés ftiáchnoun skēnikés gia na prostatévoun apó ton vrochó.
Pirates build tents to protect from the rain.

definition: A structure that provides cover on top of a building or shelter
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word στέγη meaning 'roof'
example: Η στέγη του σπιτιού τους ήταν σταθερή και αξιόπιστη.
I stégi tou spitiu tus itan statherí ke aksiópista.
Their house roof was stable and reliable.

definition: A path or track, especially one through a jungle or forest.
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'τρέχειν' (trechein), meaning 'to run' or 'to move quickly'.
example: Το τροχιά του λάσκου πήγε από την κοιλάδα μέχρι την πεδιάδα.
To trochia tou laskou pge apo tin koilada mechi tin pediada.
The path of the leopard went from the valley to the plain.

definition: A stance or position, especially one taken in preparation for movement or action.
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'στάζειν' (stazein), meaning 'to stand'.
example: Η στάση του λεόπτρου ήταν έτοιμη για την στροφή.
I stasi tou leoptrou itan etimi gia tin strofi.
The stance of the leopard was ready for the turn.

definition: An inhabitant or resident, especially of a jungle o
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'κατοικέω' (kato
example: Οι κάτοικοι της ζούγκλας ήταν πειρατές.
Oi katoikoi tis zougklas itan peirates.
The inhabitants of the jungle were pirates.

definition: used to describe something that is light in weight or appearance
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'ελαφρός' (elaphros) meaning 'light, graceful'
example: Ο ελαφρός στρατιώτης ήταν έτοιμος για την περιπέτεια στο δάσος.
The light soldier was ready for the adventure in the jungle.
The light soldier was ready for the adventure in the jungle.

definition: used to describe a place or position that is close or near
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'πλησίον' (plision) meaning 'near, close'
example: Το πλησίον καταφύγιο βρίσκεται εκεί που ξεκινάει η ζούγκλα.
The close refuge is located where the jungle begins.
The close refuge is located where the jungle begins.

definition: used to describe a place that is deserted or lacking in people or vegetation
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'ερημικός' (erimikos) meaning 'desolate, deserted'
example: Το ερημικό δάσος ήταν γεμάτο από πειρατές και τεράτα.
The desolate jungle was full of pirates and monsters.
The desolate jungle was full of pirates and monsters.

definition: A primate with long arms and a tail, often found in jungle habitats.
etymology: From ancient Greek μαῖα (maia), meaning 'mother'. This was used to describe the monkey's playful, child-like behavior.
example: Τα μαϊμού παίζουν στη ζούγκλα.
Ta maiumu paizoun sti zóungla.
The monkeys are playing in the jungle.

definition: Serving as a good or typical example of a particular type of thing.
etymology: From ancient Greek παράδειγμα (paradeigma), meaning 'example', and -ικός (-ikos), meaning 'related to, connected with'.
example: Το μαϊμού είναι παραδειγματικό ζώο της ζούγκλας.
To maiumu einai paradeigmatikó zóo tis zóunglas.
The monkey is a representative animal of the jungle.

definition: Of or relating to dense forests with abundant vegetation, found in tropical regions.
etymology: From ancient Greek δάσος (dasos), meaning 'forest'. This adjective form was created to describe the specific characteristics of the tropical jungle forests.
example: Η ζούγκλα είναι ένα δασικό κλίμα.
I zóungla einai éna dasikó klíma.
The jungle is a jungle climate.

definition: having the property of repeating, or looping back, on itself
etymology: from the ancient Greek word 'anakyklōtos' which means 'circular'
example: Οι ανακυκλωτικές συνθήκες στη ζούγκλα παρέχουν τροφή για πολλά ζώα.
Oi anakyklotikes synthikes sti zougla parechoun trophi gia polla zoa.
The recursive conditions in the jungle provide food for many animals.

definition: having many different forms, elements, or styles
etymology: from the ancient Greek word 'anektikos' which means 'various'
example: Η ζούγκλα έχει μια ανεκτική ποικιλία ζώων και φυτών.
I zougla echei mia anektiki poikilia zoon kai fyton.
The jungle has a diverse variety of animals and plants.

definition: having a soft, smooth, or soothing quality or character
etymology: from the ancient Greek word 'apalos' which means 'smooth, delicate'
example: Η στέγη στο χέρσο της ζούγκλας ήταν απαλή και ήσυχη.
I stegi stochersos tis zouglas itan apali kai isyhi.
The shelter on the jungle's edge was

definition: A dense, tangled mass of trees, shrubs, and undergrowth in a tropical rainforest.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'στασάω' meaning 'to stand in confusion'
example: Η στασαλία ήταν πολύ καλύτερη παραδειγματική του ζούγκλα
Hē stasalia ētan polý kalýteri paradigmatikì tou zoúngla
The tangled mass was a very good example of the jungle.

definition: A person who leads an expedition into a new and unfamiliar area, especially into a jungle.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'στρατηγέω' meaning 'to be a general'
example: Ο στρατηγός ήταν ένας εμπειρογνωμόνες της ζούγκλας
O stratigo̱s ētan énas empeirognómones tis zoúnglas
The explorer was an expert of the jungle.

definition: An animal that lives by hunting other animals for food, especially in the jungle.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'ταράσσω' meaning 'to disorder'
example: Τα πειρατές πρέπει να είναι προσεκτικοί για ταρακτήρες της ζούγκλας
Ta peiratés prépei na eínai prosektikoí gia taraktíres tis zoúnglas
The explorers need to be careful for the predators of

definition: The act of examining or inspecting something.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek verb 'επισκέπτομαι' (episképtomai), meaning 'to inspect'.
example: Η επισκοπή της ζούγκλας πρέπει να γίνεται συχνά.
H episkepsis tis zounglas prepei na ginei sychna.
The inspection of the jungle should be done frequently.

definition: Not capable of being penetrated or passed through.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek verb 'απαρέμφατος' (aparémfatos), meaning 'impenetrable'.
example: Η ζούγκλα είναι απαρέμφατος.
I zoungla einai aparemfatos.
The jungle is impenetrable.

definition: A person who hunts or catches spiders.
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'αράχνη' (arákhne), meaning 'spider' and the suffix '-ιστής' (-istis), meaning 'one who does' .
example: Ο αραχνιστής έλαβε πολλούς αράχνες από τη ζούγκλα.
O arachnistis élave pollous arákhnes apo ti zoungla.
The spider hunter caught many spiders from the jungle.

definition: describing something that is squeezed or compressed in a narrow space or confined area
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek verb στένω (stenō) meaning 'to squeeze, compress'
example: Τα στεναγμένα σκαλοπάτια ήταν επικίνδυνα.
Ta stenagmena skalopatia itan epikindyna.
The squeezed stairs were dangerous.

definition: the act of disguising or hiding one's true identity or appearance in order to blend in or avoid detection
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek words ταυτός (tautos) meaning 'the same' and τρέπω (trepō) meaning 'to turn'
example: Η ταυτοτροπία του ζώου ήταν ιδιαίτερα σημαντική για την προστασία του.
I tautotropia tou zōou itan idiaitera simantika gia tin prostasia tou.
The animal's disguise was particularly important for its protection.

definition: describing something that causes fear or apprehension
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek verb φρίκημι (phrikēmi) meaning 'to frighten'
example: Τα φρικαλεός τέρατα της ζούγκλας ήταν ιδιαίτερα αποκαλυπτικά.
Ta frikaleos terata tis zōuglas itan idiaitera ap

definition: A person who oversees or is responsible for a particular task or area of work
etymology: Derived from the Greek verb 'επίστασθαι' (epistasthai) meaning 'to stand over, to inspect, to oversee'
example: ο επιστατής του δάσους παρακολούθησε την στέγη των ζώων.
ho epistatēs tou dasous parakolouthēse tin stégē ton zōōn.
The superintendent of the jungle monitored the shelter of the animals.

definition: A narrow and winding way or track, especially through a dense forest or jungle
etymology: Derived from the Greek verb 'στενάζω' (stenazō) meaning 'to narrow'
example: οι πειρατές πήγαν κατά το στενάγμα στην ζούγκλα.
oi peiratēs pēgan katá to stenagma stin zoúngla.
The pirates went through the path to the jungle.

definition: An act or instance of breaking or tearing apart, or the state of being broken or torn apart
etymology: Derived from the Greek verb 'σπάω' (spao) meaning 'to break'
example: ένας σπασμός στην ρίχτη του δάσους σταμάτησε την περίπατο των θηρευτών.
enas spasmos stin ríchtē tou

definition: dark, dense, or soiled; black in color
etymology: From Proto-Indo-European *melh₂-
example: Τα μέλα μέλια είναι πιο γλυκά από τα λευκά.
Ta mela melia einai pio glyka apo ta leuka.
Black honey is sweeter than white honey.

definition: to domesticate, train, or make fit for a human purpose
etymology: From the root παθ- (path-)
example: Ο θηρευτής παντρεύτηκε τον τέρας για να στηριξει την σκηνή του.
O theveretes pantreute ton teras gia na stiriksei tin skini tou.
The hunter tamed the monster to support his tent.

definition: serving as a model or example; admirable
etymology: From παράδειγμα (paradeigma, example) and -ικός (-ikos, adjectival suffix)
example: Οι κατοίκοι της ζούγκλας ήταν παραδειγματικοί για την στάση τους στην πειρασμό.
I katoikoi tis zounglas itan paradeigmatikoi gia tin stasi tous stin perasmos.
The residents of the jungle were exemplary for their stance in the challenge.

definition: having a profuse and luxurious growth, abundant, rich
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'τάλαντον' (talanton) meaning 'balance, scale, a weight'
example: το ταλαντώδες δάσος είναι πλούσιο σε φυτά και ζώα
to talantodēs dasos einai ploúsio se fyta kai zōa
The luxuriant jungle is rich in plants and animals

definition: a person who robs or commits illegal acts at sea
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek word 'πειρατεία' (peirateia) meaning 'piracy, robbery on the seas'
example: οι πείρατες εκτοπίζουν τα πλοία στα εξωτικά κυκλαδικά νησιά
oi peirates ektopízoun ta ploía sta exotika kykladika nisia
Pirates intercept ships in the exotic Cycladic islands

definition: an act of putting to proof, trial, or the like; experiment, an enticement to do wrong
etymology: Derived from the Ancient Greek verb 'πειράζω' (peirazō) meaning 'to try, test'
example: ο θηρευτής χρησιμοποιεί την πειρασμή για να ανακαλύψει τη δύναμη του θύραγα

definition: A river with fast-moving currents and waterfalls
etymology: Derived from the Greek words 'kata' meaning 'down' and 'pontos' meaning 'sea'.
example: Η καταποντίστρα ήταν στενή και ανεπανάστατη.
Hē katapontistra ētan stenē kai anepanastatē.
The river rapids were narrow and untamed.

definition: The lush and dense growth of plants found in a jungle
etymology: Derived from the Greek word 'phren' meaning 'mind' or 'diaphragm', possibly referencing the dense growth of vegetation.
example: Η φρεναρία ήταν πολύ πικρή και αδύνατη για την περίδραση.
Hē phrenaria ētan poly pikrē kai adunatēk gia tēn peridrasi.
The jungle vegetation was very thick and impenetrable to navigate through.

definition: Tending to be susceptible to or characterized by floods.
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word κατάποντας (katapontas) meaning 'to flow downwards'.
example: Η ζούγκλα είναι ένα καταποντικό ενδιάμεσο ενδιαίτηρο.
Hē zounkla einai ena katapontiko endiameno endiatero.
The jungle is a flood-prone intermediate environment.

definition: Of or relating to hunting, or the pursuit of game or wild animals for sport or food.
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word θηρεύω (thēreuō) meaning 'to hunt, pursue'.
example: Η ζούγκλα είναι ένα θηρευτικό περιβάλλον.
Hē zounkla einai ena thēreutiko periballon.
The jungle is a hunting environment.

definition: Relating to or providing a place of habitation, dwelling or residence.
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word κατοικία (katoikia) meaning 'dwelling place, habitation, residence'.
example: Η ζούγκλα είναι μια κατοικητική περιοχή για είδικα πειρασμένα ζώα.
Hē zounkla einai mia katikētiki per

definition: A temporary settlement or dwelling place, especially one established by an army for military purposes.
etymology: Derived from 'κατασκήνωσις' (kataskenōsis), from 'κατά' (kata), meaning 'down' and 'σκηνή' (skēnē), meaning 'tent' or 'dwelling place'
example: Οι πείρατες κατασκήνωσαν στη ζούγκλα για να εκτοπίσουν νέες πείρασεις.
Oi peirates kataskenōsan sti zōngla gia na ektopisoun nees peiraseis.
The pirates established an encampment in the jungle for new explorations.

definition: Causing fear or alarm; having a scary appearance or
etymology: Derived from 'φρίκη' (phrikē), meaning 'fright' or '
example: Η φρικαλεός ζούγκλα έκανε τους πειραστές να είναι προσεκτικοί
I phrikaleós zōngla ekane tous peirastes na einai prosektikoi
The frightening jungle made the explorers cautious.

definition: a dense group of bushes or trees
etymology: Derived from the Greek word 'στροβίλος' meaning 'twisted' or 'wound up'
example: Το στροβιλία ήταν πολύ παχύ και αδύνατο να περάσει ο επισκέπτης.
To strovilía itan polý pachý ke adýnato na perási o episképtis.
The thicket was very thick and the visitor was unable to pass through.

definition: a dense forest in a tropical region
etymology: Derived from the Greek word 'δάσος' meaning 'forest' or 'wood'
example: Οι πειρατές αναζητούσαν το κλειδί στην δασική για να βρουν την πόλη των ελέφαντων.
I piretés anazitousán to kleidí stin dasikí gia na vroun tin póli ton elfanton.
The pirates were searching for the key in the jungle to find the city of the elephants.

definition: intended for or involved in exploring or discovering new information
etymology: Derived from the Greek word 'εντοπίζω' meaning 'to discover' or 'to find'
example: Η εντοπιστική εκστρ

definition: a narrow passageway in a jungle or forest
etymology: From the Greek word 'στενός' meaning 'narrow' and 'χωρίον' meaning 'place'
example: Η στενοχωρία ήταν ένας τρόπος να διασχίσουν τα σκαλωσιές.
Hē stenochoria ētan enas trópos na diaschísoun ta skalosiés.
The narrow pass was a way to cross the cliffs.

definition: related to hunting or the act of hunting
etymology: From the Greek word 'θήρα' meaning 'hunt'
example: Ο θηριακός στρατηγός υποστηρίζει την καταπολέμηση των αντιπάλων.
O thiriakós stratigós ypostirízi tin katapolémisi ton antipálon.
The hunting commander supports the defeat of the enemies.

definition: a vine growing in the jungle
etymology: From the Greek word 'ζούγκλα' meaning 'jungle' and 'οίνος' meaning 'vine'
example: Το ζούγκλο συνήθως είναι στερεό και χρήσιμο για την ασφάλεια.
To zouglo siníthos eínai stereó kai chrísimo g

definition: A temporary shelter or quarters for troops in a military campaign
etymology: From the ancient Greek word 'stratos' meaning 'army' and 'pedion' meaning 'ground'
example: Το στρατόπεδο των στρατιωτών ήταν στην κορυφή του βουνού.
To stratopedo ton stratiotón ítan stin koryfí tou vounoú.
The soldiers' encampment was on top of the mountain.

definition: Relating to the armed forces or military
etymology: Derived from the ancient Greek word 'stratos' meanin
example: Το στρατιωτικό στρατόπεδο ήταν στο πέρασμα της ζούγκλας.
To stratiotiko stratopedo ítan sto perasma tis zoúglas.
The military encampment was in the jungle pass.

definition: A person responsible for the management and care of
etymology: From the ancient Greek word 'dasos' meaning 'forest'
example: Ο δασοκόμος παρακολούθησε την εκτοπιστική στρατιά στη ζούγκλα
O dasokomos parakolúthese tin ektopistiki stratía sti zoúgla.
The forester followed the exploratory army into the jungle.
